ground_truth: Lizzie is sitting on Jane's sickbed and gently strokes her sleeping sister's face. Jane slowly opens her eyes and looks weakly at Lizzie, who gives her a hopeful smile. In the dining room, Miss Bingley's good humor fades, and someone stalks across the room as Lizzie is shown in. Two spaniels frighten pheasants from a bush as Lizzie watches the shooting party from Jane's bedroom window. She turns to look at her pale sister, who smiles weakly up at her, and Lizzie smiles back tearfully. The hunting party makes its way back to Netherfield Hall under a twilight sky. Lizzie turns away from a mirror, wearing a white silk gown, and the sisters smile at each other. Lizzie then walks down a staircase, looks around uncertainly, and is startled by a footman. She smiles gratefully, looks around nervously, unsure of where the drawing room is, and walks into a dark corridor. She enters the billiard room where Darcy is playing alone, and he swiftly bows to her. Hesitating in the doorway for a moment, she hurries out, while Darcy looks after her thoughtfully before continuing his game. Later, Lizzie is reading a book in the drawing room. Darcy glances at the card game in progress, then crosses over to Lizzie and takes a seat at a desk while eyebrows are raised. Darcy realizes he is being spoken to, and Lizzie smiles as he holds her in a steady, thoughtful gaze. Mrs. Bennet is being driven in a carriage as Lydia and Kitty excitedly poke their heads out of the window to see the grand red brick facade of Netherfield Hall. Mrs. Bennet and the girls are shown in. Meanwhile, Darcy walks away, and Mr. Bingley glares at his sniggering sisters before Lizzie takes a seat. Bingley glances over at Darcy, and Lizzie closes her eyes in embarrassment. Darcy is then seen washing in a copper bath as a servant enters and pours a large jug of water over his head and back. Darcy flicks water from his hair, leans back on towels against the high end of the bath, leaves himself out of the bath, and into a dressing gown held open for him by a servant. He wraps the robe around himself and crosses to the window, where he sees Lizzie in the garden below. She is playing with a dog, trying to wrestle a stick from its mouth. Standing at the window, Darcy watches her every move. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst is fast asleep in a chair while Mrs. Hurst is also seated.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Lizzie is seated on Jane's sickbed and tenderly caresses her slumbering sibling's visage. Jane gradually opens her eyes and gazes feebly at Lizzie, who offers her an optimistic grin. In the dining chamber, Miss Bingley's cheerful demeanor diminishes, and someone strides across the chamber as Lizzie is ushered in. Two spaniels scare pheasants from a shrub as Lizzie observes the shooting group from Jane's bedroom casement. She turns to look at her pallid sister, who grins feebly up at her, and Lizzie grins back tearfully. The hunting party makes its way back to Netherfield Hall under a dusk sky. Lizzie turns away from a mirror, attired in a white silk robe, and the siblings grin at each other. Lizzie then moves down a staircase, glances around uncertainly, and is surprised by a footman. She grins gratefully, glances around anxiously, unsure of where the drawing chamber is, and proceeds into a dim corridor. She enters the billiard chamber where Darcy is playing unaccompanied, and he quickly inclines to her. Pausing in the entryway for a moment, she rushes out, while Darcy regards her thoughtfully before resuming his game. Later, Lizzie is perusing a tome in the drawing chamber. Darcy glances at the card game in progress, then traverses over to Lizzie and takes a seat at a bureau while eyebrows are raised. Darcy realizes he is being addressed, and Lizzie grins as he holds her in a steady, contemplative gaze. Mrs. Bennet is being driven in a carriage as Lydia and Kitty excitedly poke their heads out of the aperture to see the grand red brick facade of Netherfield Hall. Mrs. Bennet and the girls are ushered in. Meanwhile, Darcy strides away, and Mr. Bingley scowls at his chuckling sisters before Lizzie takes a seat. Bingley glances over at Darcy, and Lizzie closes her eyes in chagrin. Darcy is then seen cleansing in a copper tub as a servant enters and pours a large pitcher of water over his head and back. Darcy flicks water from his hair, reclines on towels against the high end of the tub, lifts himself out of the tub, and into a dressing robe held open for him by a servant. He wraps the robe around himself and crosses to the window, where he perceives Lizzie in the garden below. She is playing with a canine, trying to wrest a stick from its mouth. Positioned at the window, Darcy observes her every move. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst is fast asleep in a chair while Mrs. Hurst is also seated.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Lizzie is sitting on Jane's sickbed, and her sleeping sister's face is gently stroked by her. Jane's eyes are slowly opened, and she looks weakly at Lizzie, who is given a hopeful smile by her. In the dining room, Miss Bingley's good humor fades, and someone stalks across the room as Lizzie is shown in. Two spaniels frighten pheasants from a bush as the shooting party is watched by Lizzie from Jane's bedroom window. She turns to look at her pale sister, who gives her a weak smile, and Lizzie is smiled back at tearfully. The way back to Netherfield Hall is made by the hunting party under a twilight sky. Lizzie turns away from a mirror, wearing a white silk gown, and each sister is smiled at by the other. Then, a staircase is walked down by Lizzie, and she looks around uncertainly, and a footman startles her. A smile is given gratefully by her, and she looks around nervously, unsure of where the drawing room is, and a dark corridor is walked into by her. The billiard room is entered by her, where Darcy is playing alone, and a swift bow is made to her by him. Hesitating in the doorway for a moment, she hurries out, while she is looked after thoughtfully by Darcy before his game is continued. Later, a book is being read by Lizzie in the drawing room. The card game in progress is glanced at by Darcy, then he crosses over to Lizzie and takes a seat at a desk while eyebrows are being raised. Realizing he is speaking, Darcy holds her in a steady, thoughtful gaze, and Lizzie smiles. Mrs. Bennet is driving in a carriage as Lydia and Kitty excitedly poke their heads out of the window to see the grand red brick facade of Netherfield Hall. Mrs. Bennet and the girls are shown in. Meanwhile, Darcy walks away, Mr. Bingley glares at his sniggering sisters before a seat is taken by Lizzie. Bingley glances over at Darcy, and Lizzie's eyes are closed in embarrassment. Darcy is then seen washing in a copper bath as a servant pours a large jug of water over his head and back. Water is flicked from his hair by Darcy, he leans back on towels against the high end of the bath, gets out of the bath, and into a dressing gown held open by a servant. The robe is wrapped around himself by him, and he crosses to the window, where Lizzie is seen in the garden below. She is playing with a dog, trying to wrestle a stick from its mouth. Her every move is watched by Darcy as he stands at the window. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst is fast asleep in a chair while his seat is also taken by Mrs. Hurst.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Lizzie sits by Jane's sickbed, gently stroking her sister's face. Jane weakly opens her eyes, and Lizzie smiles hopefully. In the dining room, Miss Bingley's mood sours as Lizzie enters. Two spaniels scare pheasants from a bush as Lizzie watches the shooting party from Jane's window. She turns to her pale sister, who smiles weakly, and Lizzie smiles back tearfully. The hunting party returns to Netherfield Hall under a twilight sky. Lizzie, in a white silk gown, smiles at Jane before descending the staircase. Startled by a footman, she nervously searches for the drawing room, entering a dark corridor. She finds Darcy playing billiards; he bows, and she hurries out as he watches thoughtfully. Later, Lizzie reads in the drawing room. Darcy, noticing the card game, sits at a desk, raising eyebrows. He realizes someone is speaking to him, and Lizzie smiles as he gazes at her thoughtfully. Mrs. Bennet arrives in a carriage with Lydia and Kitty, who eagerly view Netherfield Hall. Inside, Darcy walks away as Mr. Bingley glares at his sisters. Lizzie sits, embarrassed, as Bingley glances at Darcy. Darcy is seen bathing, a servant pouring water over him. He wraps in a robe and looks out the window, watching Lizzie play with a dog in the garden. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst sleeps in a chair, and Mrs. Hurst sits nearby.

test_cases.description: Lizzie sits on Jane's sickbed, gently stroking her sleeping sister's face. Jane weakly opens her eyes, and Lizzie smiles hopefully. In the dining room, Miss Bingley's mood sours as Lizzie enters. Two spaniels scare pheasants as Lizzie watches the shooting party from Jane's window. She turns to her pale sister, who smiles weakly, and Lizzie smiles back tearfully. The hunting party returns to Netherfield Hall at twilight. Lizzie, in a white silk gown, smiles at Jane, then descends the stairs, startled by a footman. Mrs. Bennet arrives in a carriage with Lydia and Kitty, who eagerly view Netherfield Hall. Mrs. Bennet and the girls enter as Darcy walks away. Mr. Bingley glares at his sisters before Lizzie sits, embarrassed. Darcy washes in a copper bath, a servant pouring water over him. He exits the bath, dons a robe, and watches Lizzie play with a dog in the garden. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst sleeps in a chair, and Mrs. Hurst sits nearby.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Lizzie is seated on Jane's sickbed, tenderly stroking her sleeping sister's face with gentle, loving care. Jane gradually opens her eyes, looking up at Lizzie with a weak, fragile gaze, and Lizzie responds with a hopeful, reassuring smile. Meanwhile, in the dining room, Miss Bingley's cheerful demeanor begins to fade, and someone moves purposefully across the room as Lizzie is shown in. Outside, two spaniels energetically frighten pheasants from a bush while Lizzie observes the shooting party from the vantage point of Jane's bedroom window. She turns her attention back to her pale sister, who offers a faint, weak smile up at her, and Lizzie returns the gesture with a tearful smile of her own. The hunting party makes its way back to the grand Netherfield Hall under the dimming light of a twilight sky. Lizzie turns away from a mirror, dressed elegantly in a white silk gown, and the sisters exchange warm smiles. Lizzie then descends a staircase, glancing around with uncertainty, and is momentarily startled by a footman. She smiles gratefully at him, looking around nervously, unsure of the location of the drawing room, and proceeds to walk into a dimly lit corridor. She enters the billiard room, where Darcy is engaged in a solitary game, and he swiftly bows to her in acknowledgment. Hesitating briefly in the doorway, she quickly hurries out, while Darcy watches her thoughtfully before resuming his game. Later, Lizzie is seen reading a book in the drawing room. Darcy, after glancing at the card game in progress, crosses over to Lizzie and takes a seat at a nearby desk, causing eyebrows to raise. Darcy becomes aware that he is being spoken to, and Lizzie smiles as he holds her in a steady, thoughtful gaze. Meanwhile, Mrs. Bennet is being driven in a carriage, with Lydia and Kitty excitedly poking their heads out of the window to catch a glimpse of the grand red brick facade of Netherfield Hall. Mrs. Bennet and the girls are shown in. At the same time, Darcy walks away, and Mr. Bingley glares at his sniggering sisters before Lizzie takes a seat. Bingley glances over at Darcy, and Lizzie closes her eyes in embarrassment. Darcy is then seen washing in a copper bath as a servant enters and pours a large jug of water over his head and back. Darcy flicks water from his hair, leans back on towels against the high end of the bath, and then steps out of the bath into a dressing gown held open for him by a servant. He wraps the robe securely around himself and crosses to the window, where he sees Lizzie in the garden below. She is playfully engaging with a dog, trying to wrestle a stick from its mouth. Standing at the window, Darcy watches her every move with keen interest. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst is fast asleep in a chair, while Mrs. Hurst is also seated nearby.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Lizzie finds herself comfortably seated on Jane's sickbed, tenderly and lovingly stroking her sleeping sister’s face with the utmost gentle care. Jane's eyes slowly and gradually open, and she looks up at Lizzie with a gaze that appears weak and fragile. In response, Lizzie offers her a hopeful and reassuring smile, filled with compassion and warmth. Meanwhile, over in the dining room, Miss Bingley’s once cheerful and vibrant demeanor begins to noticeably fade, and someone moves with a sense of purpose across the room right at the moment Lizzie is shown in. Outside the window, two lively spaniels are energetically frightening pheasants, causing them to scatter from a bush, all while Lizzie observes the shooting party from her vantage point at Jane's bedroom window. She then redirects her attention back to her sister, whose complexion remains pale, and who gives Lizzie a faint, weak smile. Lizzie warmly returns the gesture with a tearful smile of her own, touched by the exchange. The hunting party, with their activities drawing to a close, makes its way back to the grand and elegant Netherfield Hall under the softening, dimming light of the twilight sky. Lizzie turns away from her reflection in the mirror, dressed elegantly in a stunning white silk gown, and the sisters exchange warm, affectionate smiles once again. Lizzie then gracefully descends a grand staircase, glancing around with a sense of uncertainty, and she is momentarily startled by the sudden presence of a footman. She smiles at him gratefully, while still looking around nervously, unsure of where exactly the drawing room is located, and she proceeds to walk into a dimly lit corridor. As she enters the billiard room, she finds Darcy engaged in a solitary game, and he swiftly acknowledges her presence with a polite bow. Hesitating for a brief moment in the doorway, she quickly hurries out, all while Darcy watches her thoughtfully before resuming his game. Later on, Lizzie is seen engrossed in a book in the drawing room. Darcy, after briefly glancing at the card game in progress, crosses over to Lizzie and takes a seat at a nearby desk, which causes eyebrows to raise in curiosity. Darcy becomes aware that someone is speaking to him, and Lizzie smiles warmly as he holds her in a steady and thoughtful gaze. Meanwhile, Mrs. Bennet is being driven in a carriage, with Lydia and Kitty excitedly poking their heads out of the window, eager to catch a glimpse of the grand red brick facade of the imposing Netherfield Hall. Mrs. Bennet and the girls are shown in at the same time. Concurrently, Darcy walks away, and Mr. Bingley glares disapprovingly at his sniggering sisters before Lizzie takes a seat. Bingley glances over at Darcy, and Lizzie closes her eyes in embarrassment, overwhelmed by the situation. Darcy is then seen engaged in washing in a copper bath, as a servant enters and carefully pours a large jug of water over his head and back. Darcy flicks water from his hair, leans back on towels propped against the high end of the bath, and then steps confidently out of the bath into a dressing gown held open for him by a servant. He wraps the robe securely and comfortably around himself and crosses over to the window, where he sees Lizzie in the garden below. She is playfully engaging with a dog, good-naturedly trying to wrestle a stick from its mouth. Standing at the window with rapt attention, Darcy watches her every move with keen and focused interest. Meanwhile, inside, Mr. Hurst is fast asleep in a chair, while Mrs. Hurst is also seated nearby, appearing equally detached.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Lizzie is seated on Jane's sickbed, her hand moving gently as she strokes her sleeping sister's face with tender care. Jane's eyelids flutter open slowly, revealing her eyes as she gazes weakly at Lizzie, who responds with a hopeful smile that lights up her face. In the dining room, the atmosphere shifts as Miss Bingley's good humor dissipates, and the sound of footsteps echoes as someone stalks across the room just as Lizzie is shown in. Outside, two spaniels burst forth, startling pheasants from a bush, while Lizzie stands at Jane's bedroom window, her eyes following the shooting party. She turns her attention back to her sister, whose pale face is illuminated by a weak smile directed at Lizzie, who returns the gesture with a tearful smile of her own. As the hunting party makes its way back to Netherfield Hall under the dimming twilight sky, Lizzie turns away from a mirror, her reflection showing her clad in a white silk gown, and exchanges a warm smile with her sister. Lizzie then descends the staircase, her eyes scanning her surroundings with uncertainty, and she is momentarily startled by the sudden appearance of a footman. She offers him a grateful smile, her gaze darting around nervously as she tries to locate the drawing room, and she ventures into a dark corridor. Her steps lead her into the billiard room, where Darcy is engaged in a solitary game, and he acknowledges her presence with a swift bow. Lizzie hesitates in the doorway, her mind racing, before she hurries out, leaving Darcy to watch her retreat thoughtfully before he resumes his game. Later, Lizzie is absorbed in a book in the drawing room, her attention momentarily diverted as Darcy glances at the card game in progress before making his way over to her. He takes a seat at a desk, drawing the attention of others as eyebrows are raised. Realizing he is being addressed, Darcy turns his steady, thoughtful gaze towards Lizzie, who responds with a smile. Meanwhile, Mrs. Bennet is being driven in a carriage, her daughters Lydia and Kitty eagerly poking their heads out of the window to catch a glimpse of the grand red brick facade of Netherfield Hall. Upon arrival, Mrs. Bennet and the girls are shown in, while elsewhere, Darcy walks away, and Mr. Bingley casts a glare at his sniggering sisters before Lizzie takes a seat. Bingley glances over at Darcy, and Lizzie closes her eyes, feeling a wave of embarrassment wash over her. In a different setting, Darcy is seen in a copper bath, water cascading over him as a servant pours a large jug over his head and back. He flicks water from his hair, leans back against towels at the high end of the bath, and then rises, stepping out of the bath and into a dressing gown held open by a servant. He wraps the robe around himself and crosses to the window, where his gaze falls upon Lizzie in the garden below. She is engaged in a playful struggle with a dog, attempting to wrestle a stick from its mouth, and Darcy stands at the window, captivated by her every move. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst is fast asleep in a chair, oblivious to his surroundings, while Mrs. Hurst remains seated nearby.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Lizzie sits by Jane's sickbed, gently stroking her sister's face until Jane weakly opens her eyes, prompting a hopeful smile from Lizzie. In the dining room, Miss Bingley's mood shifts as Lizzie enters. Outside, Lizzie observes the shooting party from Jane's window, then turns to exchange a tearful smile with her pale sister. As the hunting party returns to Netherfield Hall at twilight, Lizzie, now in a white silk gown, shares a smile with Jane before descending the staircase. Startled by a footman, she navigates the dark corridor uncertainly and enters the billiard room where Darcy is playing. After a brief, thoughtful exchange, she hurries out, leaving Darcy to ponder. Later, Lizzie reads in the drawing room as Darcy, after glancing at a card game, takes a seat nearby, engaging her with a steady gaze. Meanwhile, Mrs. Bennet and her daughters arrive at Netherfield Hall, greeted by its grand facade. Inside, Darcy departs as Mr. Bingley exchanges glances with Lizzie, who closes her eyes in embarrassment. In a private moment, Darcy bathes, assisted by a servant, before donning a dressing gown and moving to the window. There, he watches Lizzie play with a dog in the garden below, captivated by her every move. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst sleeps in a chair as Mrs. Hurst sits nearby.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Lizzie is sitting on Jane's sickbed in the guest room of Netherfield Hall and gently strokes her sleeping sister's face. Jane, who had caught a cold after being caught in the rain during a visit to the nearby town of Meryton, slowly opens her eyes and looks weakly at Lizzie, who gives her a hopeful smile. In the dining room, Miss Bingley's good humor fades, representing her often capricious and competitive nature, and someone stalks across the room as Lizzie is shown in. Two spaniels, breeds historically favored by the aristocracy for hunting companionship, frighten pheasants from a bush as Lizzie watches the shooting party with refined guests from Jane's bedroom window. She turns to look at her pale sister, who smiles weakly up at her, and Lizzie smiles back tearfully, moved by her sister's fragile condition. The hunting party, a common pastime for the wealthy landed gentry, makes its way back to Netherfield Hall under a twilight sky. Lizzie turns away from a mirror, wearing a white silk gown, an attire choice reflecting fashion trends of the Regency era, and the sisters smile at each other. Lizzie then walks down a grand staircase, looks around uncertainly, and is startled by a footman, part of the household staff at such estates. She smiles gratefully, looks around nervously, unsure of where the drawing room is, and walks into a dark corridor. She enters the billiard room, a space of leisure for gentlemen, where Darcy is playing alone, and he swiftly bows to her. Hesitating in the doorway for a moment, she hurries out, while Darcy looks after her thoughtfully before continuing his game. Later, Lizzie is reading a book, possibly a novel by a contemporary author like Ann Radcliffe, in the drawing room. Darcy glances at the card game in progress, a whist perhaps, then crosses over to Lizzie and takes a seat at a desk while eyebrows are raised at his unexpected social interest. Darcy realizes he is being spoken to, and Lizzie smiles as he holds her in a steady, thoughtful gaze. Mrs. Bennet is being driven in a carriage, a common mode of transportation for families of means, as Lydia and Kitty excitedly poke their heads out of the window to see the grand red brick facade of Netherfield Hall, an impressive example of Georgian architecture. Mrs. Bennet and the girls are shown in. Meanwhile, Darcy walks away, and Mr. Bingley glares at his sniggering sisters before Lizzie takes a seat. Bingley glances over at Darcy, and Lizzie closes her eyes in embarrassment, aware of the social tensions. Darcy is then seen washing in a copper bath, a luxurious amenity at the time, as a servant enters and pours a large jug of water over his head and back. Darcy flicks water from his hair, leans back on towels against the high end of the bath, and leaves himself out of the bath, into a dressing gown held open for him by a servant. He wraps the robe, made of fine fabric such as velvet, around himself and crosses to the window, where he sees Lizzie in the garden below. She is playing with a dog, a common sight in country estates, trying to wrestle a stick from its mouth. Standing at the window, Darcy watches her every move, captivated by her spirited nature. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst is fast asleep in a chair, likely having overindulged in the evening's festivities, while Mrs. Hurst is also seated, her aloof demeanor unchanged.

In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Darcy glances at the card game in progress then crosses over to Lizzie and takes a seat at a desk while eyebrows are raised. Darcy realizes he is being spoken to and Lizzie smiles as he holds her in a steady thoughtful gaze. Mrs Bennet is being driven in a carriage as Lydia and Kitty excitedly poke their heads out of the window to see the grand red brick facade of Netherfield Hall. Mrs Bennet and the girls are shown in. Meanwhile Darcy walks away and Mr Bingley glares at his sniggering sisters before Lizzie takes a seat. Bingley glances over at Darcy and Lizzie closes her eyes in embarrassment. Darcy is then seen washing in a copper bath as a servant enters and pours a large jug of water over his head and back. Darcy flicks water from his hair leans back on towels against the high end of the bath leaves himself out of the bath and into a dressing gown held open for him by a servant. He wraps the robe around himself and crosses to the window where he sees Lizzie in the garden below. She is playing with a dog trying to wrestle a stick from its mouth. Standing at the window Darcy watches her every move. Meanwhile Mr Hurst is fast asleep in a chair while Mrs Hurst is also seated.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Lizzie is sitting on Jane's sickbed and gently strokes her sleeping sister's face. Jane slowly opens her eyes and looks weakly at Lizzie who gives her a hopeful smile. In the dining room Miss Bingley's good humor fades and someone stalks across the room as Lizzie is shown in. Two spaniels frighten pheasants from a bush as Lizzie watches the shooting party from Jane's bedroom window. She turns to look at her pale sister who smiles weakly up at her and Lizzie smiles back tearfully. The hunting party makes its way back to Netherfield Hall under a twilight sky. Darcy is then seen washing in a copper bath as a servant enters and pours a large jug of water over his head and back. Darcy flicks water from his hair leans back on towels against the high end of the bath leaves himself out of the bath and into a dressing gown held open for him by a servant. He wraps the robe around himself and crosses to the window where he sees Lizzie in the garden below. She is playing with a dog trying to wrestle a stick from its mouth. Standing at the window Darcy watches her every move. Meanwhile Mr Hurst is fast asleep in a chair while Mrs Hurst is also seated.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Lizzie is sitting on Jane's sickbed and gently strokes her sleeping sister's face. Jane slowly opens her eyes and looks weakly at Lizzie who gives her a hopeful smile. In the dining room Miss Bingley's good humor fades and someone stalks across the room as Lizzie is shown in. Standing at the window Darcy watches her every move. Meanwhile Mr Hurst is fast asleep in a chair while Mrs Hurst is also seated.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Bart is lounging on Sally's dragon nest and softly juggles her snoring neighbor's tail. Sally quickly closes her mouth and listens loudly at Bart, who hands her a puzzled frown. In the library, Mr. Green's bad luck rises, and someone dances across the street as Bart is rushed in. Two raccoons invite squirrels from a chimney as Bart listens to the orchestra from Sally's attic door. He skips to glance at his colorful neighbor, who frowns strongly up at him, and Bart frowns back cheerfully. The orchestra marches its way to Robinwood Castle above a stormy sea. Bart skips away from a sofa, wearing a blue wool cape, and the neighbors frown at each other. Bart then hikes up a ladder, dances around confidently, and is frightened by a painter. He frowns sadly, dances around cheerfully, unsure of where the kitchen is, and skips into a bright tunnel. He enters the gymnasium where Ethan is swimming alone, and he slowly waves to him. Hesitating on the bench for a while, he jogs in, while Ethan chases behind him lazily before stopping his race. Later, Bart is flipping a map in the kitchen. Ethan peers at the puzzle in question, then strolls over to Bart and stands on a bench while hands are clapped. Ethan wonders if he is being sung to, and Bart frowns as he swings her in a firm, sleepy dance. Mr. Owens is being flown in a balloon as Nina and Max playfully drape their feet out of the basket to hear the small white door of Robinwood Castle. Mr. Owens and the children are rushed in. Meanwhile, Ethan sprints toward, and Mr. Green whispers at his giggling cousins before Bart stands on a bench. Green peers over at Ethan, and Bart opens his ears in delight. Ethan is then spotted dancing in a wooden box as a guard steps in and spills a tiny cup of sand over his feet and arms. Ethan kicks sand from his toes, leans forward on feathers against the low end of the box, drags himself into the box, and into a sweater held tight for him by a guard. He unwraps the scarf around himself and jogs to the curtain, where he strikes Bart in the tree below. She is shouting at a bird, trying to pull a branch from its wing. Kneeling at the curtain, Ethan hears her every step. Meanwhile, Mr. Smith is wide awake on a hammock while Mrs. Smith is also standing.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Lizzie sits by Jane's sickbed, gently stroking her sister's face until Jane weakly smiles. In the dining room, Miss Bingley's mood sours as Lizzie arrives. Watching the hunting party from Jane's window, Lizzie shares a tearful smile with Jane. Later, she wears a white gown, exchanges a smile with Jane, and descends the stairs. Unsure of her surroundings, Lizzie encounters a footman and ends up in a room where Darcy is playing billiards; he bows and she hurries out. In the drawing room, Lizzie reads while Darcy watches thoughtfully. Mrs. Bennet, Lydia, and Kitty arrive at Netherfield Hall. Bingley glances at Darcy as Lizzie closes her eyes in embarrassment. Darcy, in a bath, watches Lizzie in the garden playing with a dog. Meanwhile, Mr. Hurst sleeps in a chair.
